Dylan Efron & Boston Rob Launch YouTube Series Everything's A Competition
Source: Deadline    Published: 2025-12-01 17:00:00

By Katie Campione TV Reporter EXCLUSIVE: Dylan Efron is ready to beat Survivor legend “Boston” Rob Mariano at, well, literally everything. The reality TV stars, who first met on Peacock's The Traitors, are teaming up for a new YouTube series Everything's a Competition. Throughout the series, the friendly rivals will go head-to-head in a series of unpredictable challenges from blindfolded golf to sword fighting to pottery and much, much more. From grueling physical tasks to hilarious creative tests, nothing is off limits. Along with the trailer for the series, which is embedded above, Deadline can also exclusively reveal that the series will premiere on December 11 at 9 a.m. PT. Related Stories News Older Audiences Flocking To Influencer Content, Research Finds News YouTube TV Strikes Carriage Deal With TelevisaUnivision, Ending Two-Month Blackout “Boston Rob is a reality legend – always out strategizing, always clutch. As someone who's always loved strategy and competition, when we met on Traitors we became quick friends,” Efron said in a statement. “While we may have been in an ‘alliance' on the show, in real life – we compete… in literally everything. It's fun, it's competitive, and he's more nimble than he looks. Can't wait for people to see what happens when we're together.” Watch on Deadline Added Mariano: “Dylan is one of the guys that can just do it all, but that doesn't mean I can't still give him a run for his money. After The Traitors, we came up with the idea for Everything's a Competition because that kid loves to show off his skills, and I love to put him in his place. We've had a great time coming up with these episodes and fighting it out to see who comes out on top.” Efron and Mariano became fast friends on Season 3 of The Traitors, which saw the former outlast the competition to win the final prize as a Faithful. Mariano, a Traitor, emerged as one of the season's best personalities. On Everything's a Competition, the pair have brought their chemistry and their thrill of rivalry to every activity under the sun. Episodes will be centered around a task ranging from lawn bowling to a bromance date night of sip and paint. “At YouTube, we want to empower creators to innovate, take risks, and deliver truly engaging original content directly to their communities,” Kim Larson, Head of Creators at YouTube, said in a statement of her own. “Everything's a Competition is a fantastic example of the creative freedom creators can only find on YouTube. We are thrilled to see Dylan and Rob harness their unique chemistry and competitive spirit to build a high-quality, completely original series for their fans.“ Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Radiohead Postpone European Tour Dates Due to Thom Yorke's Throat Infection
Source: Pitchfork    Published: 2025-12-01 16:54:22

Radiohead have postponed two dates of their ongoing European tour while Thom Yorke recovers from an “extreme throat infection.” The performances, originally scheduled for tonight (December 1) and tomorrow at the Royal Arena in Copenhagen, Denmark, will now take place on December 15 and 16. Two additional shows at the same venue are set to go on as planned this Thursday (December 5) and Friday (December 6). “We are devastated to have to postpone these two shows at such short notice but Thom has been diagnosed with an extreme throat infection which has made it impossible for him to sing,” Radiohead wrote in a statement on Instagram. “We have been so blown away by the audience reactions on these dates and are loving being back on stage again; needless to say, we feel terrible that we have been forced to postpone these shows.” Radiohead kicked off their first run of shows since 2018 last month. In August, they surprise-released their second official live album, Hail to the Thief (Live Recordings 2003-2009). That same month, Radiohead scored their fourth-ever hit on Billboard's Hot 100 chart with “Let Down,” an album track from 1997's OK Computer. © 2025 Condé Nast. All rights reserved. Rihanna drapes her baby bump in jewelry in never-before-seen pregnancy photo
Source: Page Six    Published: 2025-12-01 16:31:00

Rihanna is throwing it back to her maternity era. This Thanksgiving weekend, the Barbadian singer and businesswoman is showing what she's thankful for with a photo from this past summer when she was visibly pregnant with the latest addition to her family. In September, the “Umbrella” singer gave birth to her third child with her partner A$AP Rocky — daughter Rocki Irish Mayers — a few months later, she's taking the opportunity to reminisce about her summer looks. Advertisement Though now a common practice, Rihanna was one of the first major celebrities in recent memory to embrace her pregnancy frame. Advertisement Beginning with her first pregnancy in 2022, Rihanna's maternity style has been truly remarkable. Throughout all three pregnancies, the global superstar routinely bared her growing bump in public instead of hiding behind oversized clothing or strategically placed accessories. From skin-tight looks to open-front layers, sheer tops and bejeweled belly chains, Rihanna's bump-centric ensembles get better every time. On Sunday night, the 37-year-old posted a slideshow of photos on Instagram, celebrating the 59th year of Barbados' independence from Great Britain and the 4th year as a republic. Advertisement “Barbados I L🇧🇧VE YOU!!!!” she wrote, along with a note of support for Jeffrey Bostic, Barbados' second president. The post featured several photos of Rihanna and her family at home, enjoying the sun, sand and Caribbean Sea together. Advertisement In one of the images, she poses on the beach next to the waves in a green string bikini with stacked gold bangles, her oversized pinky ring, and coordinating green sunglasses. Rihanna also donned a long belly chain that drew attention to her growing baby bump. It wasn't long after the photo was taken that Rocki entered the world on Sept. 13, 2025, making this newly released pregnancy photo an extra special moment in Rihanna's pregnancy style journey.

Reba McEntire corrects Savannah Guthrie on live TV over Rex Linn question
Source: Page Six    Published: 2025-12-01 16:31:00

Reba McEntire corrected “Today” show host Savannah Guthrie live on the air after the journalist questioned her about her fiancé, Rex Linn. The country music singer appeared on Monday's episode of the NBC program to discuss Season 2 of her sitcom “Happy's Place.” “You also met your husband there, so Rex, good ole Rex…” Guthrie said, referring to McEntire's co-star and husband-to-be. Advertisement McEntire quickly interrupted Guthrie, interjecting, “Now, wait a minute.” Advertisement “Before everybody has a conniption fit at home, we're just engaged,” she corrected her. Guthrie apologized for accidentally referring to Linn as her husband. McEntire went on to explain that she just wanted to make sure her loved ones didn't think they missed the wedding. Advertisement “My family will go, ‘Wait, you didn't tell us?!'” McEntire explained. Linn happened to be watching the interview offstage and looked completely shocked when the camera cut to him. However, his expression softened once his fiancée made the clarification on their relationship status. Advertisement “He is a workaholic, and he loves to rehearse,” McEntire gushed. “Me, not so much on the rehearsal part, so he really makes sure that I know my lines, that I'm ready to go when we have a tape day.” McEntire, 70, also said that she and Linn, 69, have had “a blast” collaborating on the series together. Want celebrity news as it breaks? “We're so grateful and thankful that we get to go to work together, work together, and then go home together,” she said. McEntire confirmed that they got engaged in December 2024, but they were waiting to share the exciting news due to the devastating LA wildfires. She spilled the beans on their engagement in September when a reporter on a red carpet referred to Linn as McEntire's “fiancé,” and she didn't correct him. Advertisement Just like their engagement announcement, the couple's wedding is going to be very “low-key.” Advertisement “A Reba, Rex wedding is going to be very different. It's going to be low-key, lots of fun, lots of people, lots of food. Our big motto is just have fun,” she said. McEntire and Linn have known each other since the '90s. However, they reconnected after McEntire's mom died in 2020, and they have been together ever since. The “Reba” alum was previously married to Charlie Battles from 1976 to 1987 and Narvel Blackstock — with whom she shares 35-year-old son Shelby — from 1989 to 2015.

Kyle Richards gives rare dating update after bombshell sexuality confession at BravoCon
Source: Page Six    Published: 2025-12-01 16:23:00

Kyle Richards issued a rare look into her love life weeks after making a bombshell reveal about her sexuality at BravoCon. When the “Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” star was asked about dating on “Live with Kelly and Mark” Monday, Richards clarified she's “not someone who's going to be on a dating app.” The Bravolebrity, 56, quipped, “That's not my style.” As for how she plans to find a partner, the reality star joked, “They have to come knock on my door. I guess I'm not going out.” Richards noted that she has been “keeping [herself] busy with work,” as well as helping plan daughter Alexia's September wedding to Jake Zingerman. “I'm fine,” she insisted, adding that her “biggest fear” after splitting from estranged husband Mauricio Umansky was “being by [her]self.” Sign up for Virtual Reali-Tea with Danny and Evan, our must-read newsletter! Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want more celebrity and pop culture news? She recalled, “I couldn't even say the word ‘single' for so long because I'm a wife and a mom. That's all my identity was.” However, the actress has found that she is “actually pretty good at” being alone. Richards and Umansky, 55, separated in the summer of 2023. The former couple has yet to file for divorce. Umansky has been romantically linked to many women post-split, with the “Buying Beverly Hills” star most recently packing on the PDA with “FBoy Island” star Celisa “CJ” Franco. Richards, for her part, sparked rampant romance rumors in 2023 with singer Morgan Wade — but repeatedly maintained they were “very close” friends as speculation swirled about her sexuality. In a Season 15 “RHOBH” trailer that aired at BravoCon last month, Richards appeared to hint she's bisexual by saying, “I could go Brad [Pitt], I could go Angelina [Jolie].” The “Little House on the Prairie” alum subsequently told Variety she made the statement to “make [her co-stars] laugh,” noting that she doesn't “like labels” but “people can think whatever they want.” Richards continued, “I am growing and evolving, and my mind has opened up. So I don't know. I don't know what the future holds now, and I'm fine with that.” When the reporters told Richards they are both lesbians, she replied, “Ha! That would never have crossed my mind before, ever in my life — and now I'm like, that's totally an option. I'm just here to see what life brings me, honestly.” She added, “I don't want to be set up with anybody. Whatever happens, happens, and I'm good with that. I like hanging out with myself alone too.” Elsewhere in the interview, the “Halloween” star called Umansky her “type: tall, dark and handsome.” The duo tied the knot in 1996, four years after Richards ended her first marriage to ex-husband Guraish Aldjufrie.

Tuc Watkins, Daria Berenato, Thomas Dekker & Brenna D'Amico Set For “Gay Zombies” Comedy-Horror ‘Zombois'
Source: Deadline    Published: 2025-12-01 16:19:00

By Andreas Wiseman Executive Editor, International & Strategy EXCLUSIVE: Tuc Watkins (The Mummy), Daria Berenato (former WWE star Sonya Deville), Thomas Dekker (Heroes) and Brenna D'Amico (Descendants) are set to star in horror-comedy Zombois from writer-director Garrett Abdo. Due to enter production in Atlanta this month, the feature centers on a group of college seniors on break in the North Georgia Mountains who discover a guarded secret and a contagion that turns their getaway into a brutal battle for survival. Rounding out the cast are Adam Huss (Power) and Aaron Goldenberg. Glendon Palmer will produce alongside Abdo, Brian Yuran and Michael Buttiglieri. Osvaldo Silvera will serve as director of photography and Jeremy O'Keefe is casting. This marks Abdo's second feature film after Exit Interviews which also starred Watkins, Huss and Dekker. Writer-director Abdo is the managing partner of the Atlanta Comedy Theater, which has helped launched a number of U.S. stand-ups.“My last film, Exit Interviews, was deeply dramatic emotional therapy so I wanted to follow it up with something totally on the opposite end of the spectrum – something fun and outrageous, so gay zombies felt like it fit the mold,” explained Abdo.Added Watkins: “Sexy, scary, and laugh-out-loud funny, Zombois is going to be one hell of a ride. I can't wait to be a part of it.”Watkins is repped by Greene Talent and Karen Forman Management. Berenato is repped by Luber Roklin Entertainment and AGMB. Dekker is repped by Untitled and D'Amico is repped by Formation and Zero Gravity. Watch on Deadline Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Amanda Seyfried Reflects on the Bravery and Vision of ‘The Testament of Ann Lee' Director Mona Fastvold
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-12-01 15:30:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. On December 4, the IndieWire Honors Winter 2025 ceremony will celebrate the creators and stars responsible for crafting some of the year's best films. Curated and selected by IndieWire's editorial team, IndieWire Honors is a celebration of the filmmakers, artisans, and performers behind films well worth toasting. In the days leading up to the Los Angeles event, IndieWire is showcasing their work with new interviews and tributes from their peers. Honoring Mona Fastvold, our Visionary Award winner and her “The Testament of Ann Lee” director, actress Amanda Seyfried reflects on her collaboration with the gentle but unwavering “Mother Mona.” Popular on IndieWire Related Stories To Build Her ‘The Testament of Ann Lee,' Filmmaker Mona Fastvold Had to Imagine Her Own Kind of Utopia ‘Pillion' Tops 2025 British Independent Film Awards Winners List Mona Fastvold and I first met years ago through mutual friends. I thought she seemed so worldly and confident. I had no idea she was a director, I was just struck by her warmth and openness. We finally got to work together in 2022 which laid a great foundation for the wild, wonderful, creatively-thrilling adventure that was “The Testament of Ann Lee.” There are a lot of ways you could tell this story, but with Mona's vision and empathy for Ann, there was no one better, you can feel her in it. She's very imaginative and unafraid of exploring the absurdity of humanity in a way I find fascinating. This was one of those once in a lifetime opportunities and I feel incredibly privileged to have been able to help bring this remarkable woman to life through her lens. With her background as a dancer, she's so musical herself and brought in the very best artisans and collaborators to help bring her vision to life. She's a natural collaborator who brings people together, which made for such a supportive, familial atmosphere on our “Ann Lee” set. “Mother Mona,” as I call her, is very clear in what she wants and also very maternal and supportive, which I love. We have an incredible shorthand at this point, she can say three words and I'll understand exactly what she wants. She guides gently and always gives me more to mine from — not all at once, but with a steady hand. Mona is one of the bravest filmmakers I know and, because of her unwavering vision, we get to explore Ann Lee's life in a beautifully unique way that celebrates her strength, leadership, and accomplishments. It's such a powerful story at a time when we desperately need them. “The Testament of Ann Lee” opens in theaters on December 25 from Searchlight Pictures. Radiohead Postpone Concerts While Thom Yorke Battles ‘Extreme Throat Infection'
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-12-01 15:26:50

By Larisha Paul Radiohead has rescheduled two nights of their four-date run at the Royal Arena in Copenhagen. In a social media statement, the band revealed that Thom Yorke is currently undergoing treatment after being diagnosed with “an extreme throat infection which has made it impossible for him to sing.” The shows originally scheduled for Dec. 1 and Dec. 2 will now take place on Dec. 15 and Dec. 16. “We are devastated to have to postpone these two shows at such short notice,” Radiohead shared in a statement. “We're hopeful Thom will recover in time to play the final two Copenhagen shows on Dec 4th and 5th.” Radiohead's appearances in Copenhagen will now bookend their four performances at the Uber Arena in Berlin from Dec. 8 through Dec. 12. “We have been so blown away by the audience reactions on these dates and are loving being back on stage again,” the statement continues. “Needless to say, we feel terrible that we have been forced to postpone these shows.” Refunds are available at the point of purchase for ticket holders who are unable to attend the rescheduled dates. Otherwise, tickets will be updated for their respective rescheduled dates. Trending Stories Buddy Guy: ‘I'm the Last Old Man Playing the Blues' Millie Bobby Brown Says She and David Harbour Have a ‘Great Relationship' Amid Bullying Rumors Evanescence to Embark on 2026 World Tour: ‘It Feels Like Everything at the Right Time' ‘The Precedent Is Flint': How Oregon's Data Center Boom Is Supercharging a Water Crisis Popular on Rolling Stone Radiohead fans have waited seven years for the band to return to the stage. Their current tour kicked off in November with appearances in Madrid, Bologna, and London. Their four sold-out shows at the O2 Arena broke an attendance record previously held by Metallica, with at least 22,200 fans in attendance on each night. At the moment, Radiohead have not announced any performances for 2026. “Last year, we got together to rehearse, just for the hell of it,” drummer Philip Selway said in a statement in September. “After a seven-year pause, it felt really good to play the songs again and reconnect with a musical identity that has become lodged deep inside all five of us. It also made us want to play some shows together, so we hope you can make it to one of the upcoming dates. For now, it will just be these ones but who knows where this will all lead.” We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Scarlett Johansson Says “It's Hard to Know” the Impact of Her Support for Woody Allen: “It's Important to Stand Up for What You Believe In”
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2025-12-01 15:16:50

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Johansson was asked about comments made to The Hollywood Reporter in 2019, where she said she loved and believed Allen after he was accused of sexual abuse by his stepdaughter. By Lily Ford In 2019, Scarlett Johansson told The Hollywood Reporter about Woody Allen: “I love Woody. I believe him, and I would work with him anytime.” The A-list actress is one of the few actors to have stayed loyal to the Oscar-winning director after his stepdaughter, Dylan Farrow, alleged he had sexually abused her as a child. Since 1992, when the claims first came to light (they were later investigated and dismissed by New York Social Services), Allen has found himself ostracized by certain corners of Hollywood and his image worsened by the #MeToo movement. He has consistently denied the claims. Related Stories Movies The Making of 'Steve': Legendary Photojournalist Don McCullin Takes Us Behind the Scenes of the Netflix Drama (Exclusive) Movies Paul Mescal Reveals His Favorite Cinematic Experience of the Year (and Tells Director: "Call Me!") In a recent interview with The Telegraph about her directorial debut, the June Squibb-starring Eleanor the Great, Johansson — who has worked with Allen on three of his films: Match Point (2005), Scoop (2006) and Vicky Cristina Barcelona (2008) — was asked about going to bat for Allen in that THR piece and how she handled the “inevitable online furore.” She was asked: What were the consequences? Related Video “I guess it's hard to know,” she responded. “You never know what the domino effect is, exactly. But my mom always encouraged me to be myself, [to see] that it's important to have integrity, and stand up for what you believe in.” “At the same time,” she continued, “I think it's also important to know when it's not your turn. I don't mean that you should silence yourself. I mean sometimes it's just not your time. And that's something I've understood more as I've matured.” Johansson also said to THR in 2019: “I see Woody whenever I can, and I have had a lot of conversations with him about it. I have been very direct with him, and he's very direct with me. He maintains his innocence, and I believe him.” The late Diane Keaton also defended Allen through the allegations (he released an emotional statement about their relationship after the news of her death broke in October). But many actors who have worked with him, including Michael Caine, Timothée Chalamet and Greta Gerwig, have publicly expressed regret about doing so. In recent years, he has struggled to secure U.S. distribution for his films. A rep for Johansson did not immediately respond to comment on her more recent statements. Also in The Telegraph piece, Johansson opens up about a financial backer of Eleanor the Great pulling out at the last minute due to Squibb's character, a Jewish woman, falsely claiming to be a Holocaust survivor. “Love the film, Scarlett, but we're not so keen on the whole Holocaust thing. Can we have the character lie about something else?” the gist of the investor's message was, according to The Telegraph. Johansson said no alternative was offered, but the character's lie was the anchor of the film. “We'd been talking about the film for so many months, and then this was the outcome?” she said. “It was really shocking, and I was so disappointed.” An “emergency ring-round” soon brought Sony Pictures Classics on board as distributors. Sign up for THR news straight to your inbox every day Send us a tip using our anonymous form.

Brian Austin Green Shares Heartache Over Loss of Beloved Friend: ‘Really Tough One'
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-12-01 15:12:26

Brian Austin Green competed on “Dancing with the Stars” Season 30. He placed 13th in the competition alongside professional dance partner Sharna Burgess, but what happened after was better than winning the Mirrorball Trophy: he and Burgess became a couple. In a November interview on Michael Rosenbaum's “Inside of You” podcast, Green spoke about dancing and his personal loss of two loved ones and dear friends. Green reflected on how he and his former co-star, the late Shannen Doherty, used to dance on the set of the hit series, “Beverly Hills, 90210.” He played the character David Silver. “She used to dance with me and my friends in my dressing room when we had time off, which we had a lot of. And, she was super fun. She was just an incredible heart,” Green said of Doherty. He also referred to her as “loyal” and “an amazing human being.” Doherty died in 2024 after a long and brave battle with cancer. Another one of Green's friends and former co-stars, Luke Perry, died in 2019. “She passed and Luke passed but in very different ways. Luke had a stroke,” Green said of the difference between Doherty and Perry's death, the latter of which came as a massive shock to fans and loved ones. Green spoke about Perry's passing, calling it “a really tough one,” and said they had spent time together not long before. “I had seen Luke not even a week before then. And we'd had lunch and he was Luke. He was the same exact person that I've known,” Green said. “And all of a sudden I got a call and it was like, ‘Hey, he's in the hospital. He had a stroke last night.' And then two days later, ‘Yeah, he didn't make it.' Like, what? What? You're kidding, right? I'm being like punked right now? This doesn't make any sense.” Doherty had bravely and publicly battled cancer, and Green reflected on how she had Stage Four breast cancer, and he had been aware of her health struggles, “for a long time.” He continued, “It wasn't in the front of my mind, but there was always that thing in the back of my mind of appreciate all of these moments because you don't know how many more you're going to get. So yeah, just enjoy all of this time that's left.” The interview was shared on YouTube, and the comment section features praise from fans for Green's kindness. “Everytime Brian Austin Green pops up in front of me, Im like, ‘Yup, still have that crush on him!' And im 44!,” a fan wrote. “Seems like a lovely dude. He's the reason I watched 90210.” “​​The only reason why I started watching BH 90201 is because of Brian and Shannon,” another fan shared. Other reactions include, “Brian was a great guest, such a fantastic IOY episode,” “It's important to be kind to yourself, to have boundaries, and to put the oxygen mask on yourself first. I love that you two are having a conversation about kindness, and it happened so naturally,” and “I went to high school with Brian. He was a solid dude. Great times!” Comment Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment. Δ Previous Next Like EntertainmentNow? Fellow Unit Member Says Alleged D.C. Shooter Felt Abandoned by CIA
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-12-01 15:00:00

By Kevin Maurer The alleged shooter of two National Guard members, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, was struggling with mental illness, his ability to support his family, and, according to an Afghan veteran who fought with him, his pleas for help to the CIA went unanswered. Lakanwal, a 29-year-old Afghan national, served in a CIA-backed Afghan force unit, known as the “Zero Units,” in Kandahar. He is facing first-degree murder charges after Army Specialist Sarah Beckstrom, 20, died of her injuries following the Wednesday shooting near the Farragut West Metro station in Washington, D.C. Air Force Staff Sergeant Andrew Wolfe, 24, remains in critical condition. Investigators are still working to establish a motive for the attack. Rolling Stone spoke to a former Afghan unit mate who pointed to financial pressure and ongoing apparent mental illness as a contributing factor. He also seems to have felt abandoned by the United States government. “He's very sad [depressed],” said Lakanwal's Afghan unit mate, who is not a native English speaker. “He's very worried. This problem, like, he'd say, ‘I am working nine years or 10 years with [the] U.S. government. [They] never answer my phone [call].'” Popular on Rolling Stone After the Taliban prevailed in America's longest running war, Lakanwal resettled in Bellingham, Washington, with his wife and five sons in September 2021. His migration was aided by Operation Allies Welcome, a Biden-era initiative to resettle vulnerable Afghans, particularly those who worked alongside U.S. forces and faced reprisals from the Taliban. The struggles to start over, leave the war behind, and find work were ever present. Lakanwal was fired from his job at a laundromat because he lacked a work authorization card despite being approved for asylum and authorized to work by the Trump administration, according to his former unit mate, who fought alongside him for more than a decade. In September, Lakanwal's nephew requested the Bellingham housing authority approve a move closer to an Afghan community. The handwritten application, reviewed by Rolling Stone, cited Lakanwal's isolation, lack of English skills, and the need to find employment in a larger community like Seattle. Lakanwal didn't feel safe in Bellingham after he was assaulted when a man sprayed something into his eyes requiring hospital treatment, according to the application. Editor's picks The 250 Greatest Albums of the 21st Century So Far The 100 Best TV Episodes of All Time “This experience has caused him stress and fear, and he does not feel comfortable continuing to live in this town,” the nephew wrote. “It is very important for him to be near his community and relatives to feel safe and to have the opportunity to find work so he can support his family.” About a month ago, Lakanwal told his unit mate that his inability to work due to missing immigration paperwork meant his family couldn't afford rent or food. He resorted to borrowing money from friends and former unit members, and during the conversation, he broke down in tears from frustration and desperation, his unit mate said. “Every time, like looking [for] somebody [to] help for documents, somebody [to] help for pay the rent, he's not going to work,” the Afghan unit mate said. His unit mate said Lakanwal sought help in June from a CIA program designed to aid Zero Unit veterans with immigration issues. Rolling Stone reviewed a screenshot of the group chat in June where Zero Unit veterans shared information with a CIA representative about ongoing issues. Lakanwal posted messages asking for help. His last post went unanswered and was deleted by the chat's administrator. Related Content Blood in the Streets Is Not a Partisan Problem Washington D.C. National Guard Shooting: Everything We Know The Taliban Drove This Afghan Trumpeter Into Exile. He Still Dreams of Home Rob Reiner Says Trump Federalizing National Guard, ICE Raids Are ‘Beyond McCarthy Era-esque' Rolling Stone called the CIA representative in the text chat, who claimed it was a wrong number. A request for comment from the CIA was not returned. Lakanwal, according to an Associated Press report and confirmed by his unit mate, would swing from “long, dark stretches of isolation,” sometimes going weeks without speaking even to his family, to “manic” episodes, during which he would take off on sudden, weekslong cross-country drives, traveling to places like Chicago or Arizona. A community advocate, according to the AP, feared Lakanwal was suicidal and asked a refugee organization for help in January 2024. The AP reported that it examined emails sent to the U.S. Committee for Refugees and Immigrants (USCRI) detailing the concerns. USCRI reportedly visited Bellingham in March 2024, but Lakanwal and his family refused their assistance, according to the AP report. Following the shooting in D.C., President Donald Trump called it a “terrorist attack” and announced a full review of all Afghan nationals admitted to the U.S. under the Biden administration. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, Vice President J.D. Vance, and FBI Director Kash Patel then collectively laid blame on former President Joe Biden, claiming Lakanwal and other refugees were “unvetted” or subject to “zero vetting,” often citing that the shooting suspect was “mass paroled into the United States.” “This individual — and so many others — should have never been allowed to come here,” CIA Director John Ratcliffe said. “Our citizens and servicemembers deserve far better than to endure the ongoing fallout from the Biden administration's catastrophic failures.” But Lakanwal, who went by “Shafiq” during his time fighting for the CIA, underwent more vetting than most Afghans. No one just joined the CIA's Zero Units. Soldiers had to be recommended by a close family member or friend. The CIA then vetted each member before even offering a probationary period. The vetting process was so successful that Zero Units never suffered an insider attack — when Afghan soldiers turned against U.S. advisers. Slots in the Zero Units were coveted because of better pay, better training, and the chance to work alongside elite U.S. operators. In later years, there were also opportunities to immigrate and resettle in the U.S. after at least one year of service and U.S. government approval. In the final days of the war in 2021, roughly 81,000 Afghan immigrants — including almost 10,000 members of the Zero Units, along with many of their families — were evacuated by the CIA and resettled across the U.S., according to reports. After arriving in the United States, the Zero Unit veterans were vetted again before receiving Special Immigrant Visas, meant for Afghan and Iraqi nationals who worked for the U.S. government. For the past year, I've been working on a documentary film about the Zero Units. For this story, I spoke to members of the community who didn't feel comfortable going on the record for fear of reprisals. All of them condemned Lankanwal's actions and struggled to understand why he would allegedly attack Americans. The Zero Unit soldiers protected CIA officers on missions and at their forward bases, so attacking American servicemembers was antithetical to their code. Now they feared his actions will make living in the United States harder. Trending Stories Buddy Guy: ‘I'm the Last Old Man Playing the Blues' Fellow Unit Member Says Alleged D.C. Shooter Felt Abandoned by CIA Millie Bobby Brown Says She and David Harbour Have a ‘Great Relationship' Amid Bullying Rumors Evanescence to Embark on 2026 World Tour: ‘It Feels Like Everything at the Right Time' The Afghan Zero Unit community is tight-knit. At one point, during a trip to Texas last year, I watched as a group of veterans took over a shisha restaurant with more than 20 sitting at one table, laughing and smoking. Bonded by combat and the pain of losing their country, they are part of a lost generation of Afghans who believed America's promise of democracy and sacrificed everything for it. But most of all Zero Unit veterans were heartbroken by Ratcliffe's comments that they should never have been allowed to come to the United States because after fighting shoulder to shoulder with the CIA for almost 20 years, they are the next sacrifice on the altar of expediency. The only certainty in U.S. foreign policy from the last helicopter out of Saigon in 1975 to the Kurds after the Gulf War in 1991 to the 2020 Doha Accords and the Afghan evacuation in 2021 is that American loyalty comes with an expiration date. We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Rolling Stone is a part of Penske Media Corporation. © 2025 Rolling Stone, LLC. All rights reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


To Build Her ‘The Testament of Ann Lee,' Filmmaker Mona Fastvold Had to Imagine Her Own Kind of Utopia
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-12-01 15:00:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. On December 4, the IndieWire Honors Winter 2025 ceremony will celebrate the creators and stars responsible for crafting some of the year's best films. Curated and selected by IndieWire's editorial team, IndieWire Honors is a celebration of the filmmakers, artisans, and performers behind films well worth toasting. In the days leading up to the Los Angeles event, IndieWire is showcasing their work with new interviews and tributes from their peers. Mona Fastvold has always been drawn to stories about women who lived their lives in the future. Women who dared to imagine how bitter pasts might give way to brighter tomorrows, and did what they could to bring those changes into being. Women — immigrants and settlers — who embodied the utopian potential of a country that has always struggled to live by its own principles, and refused to accept that they were ahead of their time. To watch her extraordinary third feature is to exult in the obvious fact that Fastvold is one of them. Related Stories Amanda Seyfried Reflects on the Bravery and Vision of ‘The Testament of Ann Lee' Director Mona Fastvold ‘Pillion' Tops 2025 British Independent Film Awards Winners List Sat across the table from me at a brunch spot near her apartment in Boerum Hill, Fastvold was understandably demure and evasive whenever I tried to frame “The Testament of Ann Lee” as something of a self-portrait; in an age where even the most innocuous of comments are spread across the internet in bad faith, it's more than a little perverse for a critic to press an artist on if and how they might see themselves reflected by the subject of a sweeping religious musical about an 18th Mancunian religious figure whose followers came to regard her as the female embodiment of God on Earth. Popular on IndieWire And yet, while Fastvold may not think of herself as the second coming of Jesus Christ (her vibe is more “chill Brooklyn mom” than “messianic herald of the rapture”), her latest film can't help but convey how deeply she identifies with Ann Lee's animating desire to shape the world anew — to devise a more hospitable framework for practicing her faith. In Fastvold's case, that faith has nothing to do with the Bible, and everything to do with her steadfast belief in a better way of making films. Where Ann Lee sought to dance herself clean from the Church of England (and its oppressive insistence that suffering is the surest path to heaven), Fastvold was and remains similarly determined to unshackle herself from the gospel truths of modern film production. At some point, it became accepted wisdom that shooting movies is supposed to be miserable. That a set has to be a giant machine that mulches dreams into labor rather than a nurturing environment that sublimates labor into dreams. That auteur-driven projects are somehow anathema to (as opposed to dependent upon) the communal joy of creating a shared purpose, and, perhaps most of all, that $10 million isn't enough money to make a spellbinding period epic. Fastvold was eager to challenge such thinking, and in the life of Ann Lee — her ecstasy, her delirium, her idealistic belief that prayer doesn't have to feel like punishment — she found the ideal vehicle through which to express her vision for how cinema might still manage to save its soul. “The Testament of Ann Lee” was born from the research process for Fastvold's previous film, a blustery historical romance that sparked her interest in the religious hymns that originated from upstate New York during the 19th century. She was fascinated by a song called “Pretty Mother's Home,” written by a freed slave who became a Shaker leader, but Fastvold wasn't looking for a story to tell so much as she was looking for a better way of telling one. “I desperately needed to reclaim the process,” Fastvold said. She's proud of the movie that left her feeling as if the process had gotten away from her (IndieWire recently named “The World to Come” as one of the 100 best films of the 2020s so far), but the Romanian shoot was unreasonably demanding, and the anxiety of staying on schedule locked the director into a creative rigidity that made the experience less rewarding for her than one might assume from the magic of the finished product. The title of the film pointed forward to a more encouraging future that its characters would never live to see for themselves, but the act of bringing its story to life was defined by all manner of inherited hardships, and the dissonance between the two left Fastvold with a bad taste in her mouth. Her frustration was deepened by the feeling that a better way of doing things was — and perhaps had always been — just out of reach. It's something she'd been thinking about for decades, ever since she began her career as an actor on a string of Norwegian soap operas. “I think everyone has a different creative process,” Fastvold said, “and I'm so grateful for all of the incredible art that exists that wasn't fun to make. I just think that because I grew up doing this and have done it my whole life that I'm really interested in the process as well.” Fastvold, who co-writes, co-produces, and co-parents with partner Brady Corbet, knows better than most directors what it's like for life and labor to intertwine, and she was fascinated with how organically Ann Lee managed to reconcile the two — more fascinated with that, even, than she was with the whole “female Christ” of it all. “What I personally connected with in Ann's journey,” Fastvold wrote in her director's statement for the film, “was the idea of creating a society not for personal gain or money, but with the intention of living inside this space where she could devote herself to work.” Fastvold was already fixated on the idea of embodying that intention in her own way, and so discovering the Shakers' story felt like the answer to a prayer. “I was like ‘I have to create that,'” she said, “and then Ann Lee came to me.” Fastvold only devotes herself to the kind of films that feel like a higher calling, and sure enough, “The Testament of Ann Lee” frames the Shakers less as a cult of personality than as a group of people bound together by their shared belief in a new way of being; as an ecstatic band of dreamers whose collective faith in the future they're creating together is strong enough to spirit them across oceans and sustain them for days of rapturous dance at a time. The film is clearly awed by Ann Lee's vision, but — in a way almost completely unique to a modern rendering of a religious figure — refuses to pass any moral judgment whatsoever about her credo. “There are things that I really struggle with in organized religion,” Fastvold said. “There are things I disagree with, and also things that I find incredible. But my hope and my goal was to not take sides, because it seemed less radical to say ‘Look at this woman and at how ridiculous or flawed she was.' I was more interested in saying: ‘Look at this complicated, strange, ambitious project she led. Look at that.'” Much like “The Brutalist” hero László Toth, who also sailed to America and busied himself with the process of building a new kind of church, Ann Lee's faith in America's utopian promise wasn't rewarded in kind. But Fastvold's film is less interested in the Shakers' ultimate fate than it is in the salvation they found through practicing their faith, and that focus was reflected in every aspect of how it was made. “I didn't want to be focused on the results,” the director said. “It couldn't just be ‘OK, I'm going to create this perfect thing.' It was stupid because I really wanted to go into it with no ego, really, and just say, ‘OK, I'm going to try something. If it's not good, it's not going to end up in the movie, but we're going to try it.' That was something I just personally needed. I needed to have moments of great joy along the way.” Fastvold had always done what she could to make sure that her sets were elastic enough to make room for real life (she recalls how many of the women in the cast and crew of “The World to Come” had small children with them, and scoffs at the notion that someone couldn't be her second AD just because they had to breastfeed), but with “The Testament of Ann Lee” she took pains to emphasize community as a guiding ethos rather than a mere accommodation. “I always really wanted to try and create an environment,” Fastvold said, “because in our industry it feels like you have to choose between having a life and making films, but if you can bring life onto a film with you don't have to miss out on it completely.” Ann Lee gave Fastvold the permission she needed to create a work environment that reminded her of home. “I'm really social and I love bringing people together,” she said. “I grew up in a family with seven children and all of their friends, so it was a very open house with people moving in and out. So for me, it's easy to say ‘OK, let's be a big family. Everyone bring their children to sets, and their dogs, and let's all just be in the circus and help take care of each other.' In the end it made everyone do a better job because they were having a good time, and we all chose to spend time with each other. On our one day off each week, we would sit and drink wine and dance and dance and dance more.” Of course, it's only natural for a director/producer to insist that everyone had the most amazing experience on their set while somehow managing to shoot a gargantuan epic in the span of 34 days for less than it cost to feed the cast of a typical blockbuster, but everyone I spoke to from “The Testament of Ann Lee” — from actors to department heads and even publicists — talked about Fastvold with the same wide-eyed fervor that we see the first Shakers talk about Ann Lee. All of them, Fastvold very much included, were quick to acknowledge that the Hungary-based shoot wasn't easy, but they were even quicker to acknowledge how empowered they felt because of their collective investment in the cause. That investment was seeded in the sense of community that Fastvold began to foster more than a year before anyone first arrived on set; it was born from the space that she created, somewhere in the overlap between work and life, for people to bring their full selves to the project. “I was working with the exact same budget limitations that I had on ‘The World to Come,'” Fastvold said, “but I knew my process depended upon creating more space to, as David Lynch would say, ‘get dreamy.' I always think about that: getting dreamy. And I was like, ‘when the hell do I have the time to get dreamy? I've never gotten dreamy in my life! But I want it. I really want to get dreamy.'” So Fastvold made the time to get dreamy, and she looked for people who were willing to do the same. She invested her faith in somewhat unknown collaborators whose talents might be enlivened by the challenge of making a wild period epic (collaborators like young production designer Sam Bader and journeyman cinematographer William Rexer, neither of whom had ever worked on a project like this), and availed herself to them for months of nights and weekends in order to obsess over the look of the film. She reconvened Oscar-winning composer Daniel Blumberg with “The Brutalist” sound designers Andy Neil and Steve Single, and encouraged them to create a wild sonic landscape that captured the emotional reality of Ann Lee's religious fervor. She asked friends like “The Last of Us Part II” actress Shannon Woodward to drive upstate for location scouting trips in the dead of winter, and freely allowed the movie to assume new shape because of what they found along the way (which helps to explain Woodward's delightful cameo as a woman who was twice her age when she actually crossed paths with Ann Lee). The “dreamy time” that Fastvold and her crew spent together during their nights and weekends away from other jobs resulted in a shorthand that allowed them to move faster, more cohesively, and at a greater scale than Hollywood allows itself to think possible. Nobody will get rich off the finished product, but it's a fitting that a film about the Shakers — a passionate sect remembered for their furniture, which they made in order to sustain their church — should counter the profit-motive that has sapped the movie industry of its vision and faith. (For her part, Fastvold credits the generosity of star Amanda Seyfried for allowing the project to remain financially sound, and for setting the tone by virtue of her own commitment to it.) “I don't mean to imply that Ann Lee never benefited from her position as the leader,” Fastvold said, “but she didn't want the fame or glory. She didn't write anything down. She was illiterate when she died, and her brother became a more prominent public speaker than she did. I just think you can have the sort of hierarchy you need for structure and safety, and at the same time not adhere to hierarchical ideas of how you speak to one another or who you include in the creative process.” Ann Lee didn't rewrite the New Testament, after all, she just tried to apply its lessons in a more equitable way — to show her followers how the process of exercising their faith could be its own reward. Her concept of heaven was no different from that of the mainstream church, but she dared to imagine, in her own wounded fashion, that the journey to get there might offer its own rewards. “We all came into this business because we are absolute fuck-ups,” Fastvold said with a laugh. “We all just love movies. We're all just little kids sitting in that dark room for the first time and being like ‘how does this magic happen in the world?' Everyone just wants to be a part of something that points to that.” With “The Testament of Ann Lee,” Fastvold has created a utopian model of her own. Like any utopia, it would be hard to emulate and virtually impossible to maintain, but the first step toward building a better future is giving people the space to imagine what it might look like. “The Testament of Ann Lee” opens in theaters on December 25 from Searchlight Pictures. Watch Sean ‘Diddy' Combs angrily confront lawyer in first glimpse at Netflix doc: ‘We're losing!'
Source: Page Six    Published: 2025-12-01 14:32:00

Sean “Diddy” Combs has a heated conversation with his lawyer in the first look at his forthcoming Netflix documentary. The streaming platform dropped the 56-second trailer for “Sean Combs: The Reckoning” on Monday, kicking off with a clip of the embattled music mogul in a New York City hotel room six days before his arrest. “We have to find somebody that'll work with us that has dealt in the dirtiest of dirty business,” the Grammy winner, 56, said in what seemed to be a phone call with his attorney. Advertisement Combs, who was wearing black athleisure in the Sept. 10, 2024, footage, appeared anxious as he repeatedly bounced his knee up and down. Advertisement “We're losing!” he angrily added. The following week, Combs was detained and charged with transportation to engage in prostitution, racketeering conspiracy and sex trafficking by force, fraud or coercion. Advertisement Start your day with Page Six Daily. Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want celebrity news as it breaks? When his eight-week trial wrapped in July, the rapper was found guilty of two counts of transportation for the purpose of prostitution — but acquitted of the other two more serious charges. Combs, who is also facing numerous sexual assault lawsuits, was sentenced to 50 months and is currently behind bars in New Jersey's Fort Dix Federal Correctional Institute. Page Six broke the news in December 2023 that 50 Cent — real name Curtis James Jackson III — was executive producing a docuseries about Combs' legal battle, which Netflix confirmed in September of the following year. Advertisement Proceeds from the series will help support survivors of sexual assault. A teaser dropped last month, promising “explosive, never-before-seen materials, including exclusive interviews with those formerly in Combs' orbit.” Monday's trailer announced that jurors will be interviewed in the four-hour-long episodes, as well as Aubrey O'Day, Combs' Bad Boy Entertainment co-founder Kirk Burrowes and more. The docuseries comes out Tuesday. Combs, whose legal team intends to appeal his conviction, was initially set to leave prison on May 8, 2028. Advertisement However, Page Six exclusively reported last month that his release date has been extended to June 4, 2028. This update came on the heels of Combs making headlines for allegedly consuming “homemade alcohol” and participating in a prohibited three-way phone call. Advertisement He has denied any wrongdoing. Alix Earle responds to Braxton Berrios breakup rumors after athlete skipped ‘DWTS' finale
Source: Page Six    Published: 2025-12-01 13:23:00

Alix Earle shut down rumors that she and Braxton Berrios split after he missed the “Dancing With the Stars” Season 34 finale last week. Over the weekend, the influencer took to TikTok to share a “Get Ready With Me” video where she gave a “post-‘DWTS' debrief” on the dancing competition's final episode. In the comments section of the post, a fan wrote, “Ugh I hope u and Braxton are still together,” to which Earle, 24, replied, “He couldn't come bc of football :(.” Berrios, who plays for the Houston Texans, had a home game against the Buffalo Bills on Nov. 20 and then an away game versus the Indianapolis Colts on Sunday. The live three-hour finale of “DWTS” was filmed on Nov. 25 in Los Angeles. Though the wide receiver, 30, could not attend, he did offer his girlfriend words of encouragement in a pre-recorded video aired during the Nov. 25 season finale. “I've watched you pour everything into this since the moment it has started, and I think it shows,” Berrios said in the clip. “Good luck. Have fun, babe,” he added. Earle ultimately lost the Len Goodman Mirrorball Trophy to Robert Irwin and his partner, Witney Carson. However, the podcaster was thankful for the close bond she and her dancing partner, Val Chmerkovskiy, formed over the course of the season. Start your day with Page Six Daily. Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want celebrity news as it breaks? “Being able to dance every day has been so amazing, so fulfilling and therapeutic, and then having such a good best friend along the way, who constantly uplifts me and supports me every day, is just so nice,” she told E! News after the live finale. Berrios and Earle were first romantically linked in May 2023 after he called it quits with ex Sophia Culpo a few months before. The pair hard-launched their romance in October 2023, in honor of the NFL star's 28th birthday. ‘Run Away' Trailer: James Nesbitt Is A Father Desperately Seeking His Daughter In Harlan Coben's Latest For Netflix
Source: Deadline    Published: 2025-12-01 12:00:00

By Max Goldbart International TV Co-Editor The Harlan Coben Netflix machine that brought the world Fool Me Once keeps on whirring. Trailer has dropped for Run Away, the latest high-stakes thriller from one of the world's most successful adaptation writers. Run Away stars James Nesbitt as Simon, whose eldest daughter Paige runs away and everything falls apart. Now, when he finds her, vulnerable and strung out on drugs in a city park, he finally has the chance to bring his little girl home. But it turns out she's not alone, and an argument escalates into shocking violence. Simon loses his daughter all over again, and his search to find her will take him into a dangerous underworld, revealing deep secrets that could tear his family apart forever. Related Stories News 'Sean Combs: The Reckoning': Teaser Trailer For Shocking Doc Shows Diddy Warn "We're Losing" News 2025 Premiere Dates For New & Returning Series On Broadcast & Streaming The series also stars Minnie Driver, Ruth Jones and Harry Potter star Alfred Enoch. Watch on Deadline It is the latest in a long line of Coben Netflix thrillers, which includes Fool Me Once, Netflix's most-watched TV show of 2024. That one was followed by Missing You. Coben has also recently made Lazarus for Prime Video. Upcoming for Netflix is an American adaptation of I Will Find You starring Sam Worthington. Run Away is made with Coben's long-term writing partner Danny Brocklehurst and producer Nicola Shindler, whose Quay Street Productions is once again producing. It also stars Lucian Msamati, Jon Pointing, Tracy-Ann Oberman, Annette Badland, Maeve Courtier-Lilley, Ellie de Lange, Adrian Greensmith, Ellie Henry, Ingrid Oliver, Finty Williams, Joe McGann and Amy Gledhill. Coben is EPing with Shindler, lead writer Brocklehurst, Richard Fee and Nimer Rashed. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. So don't go off topic, don't impersonate anyone, and don't get your facts wrong. ‘Harry Potter' Series Star Dominic McLaughlin Reacts To Letter From Daniel Radcliffe: “It Was Insane”
Source: Deadline    Published: 2025-12-01 10:11:00

By Jake Kanter International Investigations Editor Dominic McLaughlin, star of HBO‘s upcoming Harry Potter series, has recalled the moment he received a letter from Daniel Radcliffe. McLaughlin, who will play the titular wizard in the new adaptation of J.K. Rowling's books, said he was handed the letter when he was on a train home to Glasgow. “It was insane,” he beamed, during an interview with the BBC show Saturday Mash-Up! Live. “My Dad tapped me on the train and just gave me this letter. I read it and then I got to the bottom, and it said, ‘Dan R.' I was going mad, but I had to [keep cool]. I was on the train.” Watch on Deadline Related Stories Agencies Body Representing British Child Actors Blasts Equity Union For Failing To Fight For The Next Generation: "Young Performers Are Simply Not A Priority" News 'IT: Welcome to Derry's Stephen Rider Says Strike Was "Biggest Blessing" For Developing Onscreen Dynamic With Amanda Christine Asked how filming was progressing, McLaughlin replied: “It's going amazing, it's going really well. I've made good friends with everyone, it's great to be there.” Radcliffe revealed last month that he had written some words for McLaughlin. “I just see these pictures of him and the other kids and I just want to hug them,” Radcliffe said. “They just seem so young. I just look at them and say, ‘Oh it's crazy I was doing that at that age.' But it's also incredibly sweet, and I hope they're having a great time.” McLaughlin was announced as Potter in May and has been filming on the HBO series over the summer. A whopping 32,000 kids auditioned for Potter, Ron Weasley, and Hermione Granger. Alastair Stout and Arabella Stanton bagged the other two roles. McLaughlin appeared on Saturday Mash-Up! Live to promote new CBBC series Gifted, which follows a group of Scottish teens who discover they each have extraordinary powers. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Paul Mescal Reveals His Favorite Cinematic Experience of the Year (and Tells Director: “Call Me!”)
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2025-12-01 10:00:42

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter The Hollywood Reporter caught up with the Irish actor at the British Independent Film Awards in London on Sunday night. By Lily Ford It was a star-studded affair at the British Independent Film Awards (BIFA) on Sunday night. A host of the hottest talent in the U.K. and beyond took to the Roundhouse in Camden for indie cinema's biggest night of the year. Among the top winners were Pillion director Harry Lighton, I Swear frontman Robert Aramayo and breakout star of Steve, Jay Lycurgo. Joachim Trier's Sentimental Value nabbed best international feature film while Akinola Davies Jr. won the best director prize. There were even more big names on the carpet as Harris Dickinson, Alexander Skarsgard, Ruth Wilson, Carey Mulligan, Harry Melling, Frank Dillane, Tom Blyth, David Jonsson and others showed up either as nominees or to fly the flag for the British film industry. Related Video Related Stories Movies Global Styles Shake Up Oscar Animation Race Movies Kino Lorber Takes Argentine Psychodrama 'The Currents' (Exclusive) The cast of Alex Garland's A24 hit Warfare, including Joseph Quinn, Will Poulter, Kit Connor and Charles Melton, were also in attendance to pick up their best ensemble performance award. The movie rivaled Pillion in awards tallies with four wins in total. The evening took an emotional turn when Paul Mescal made a surprise appearance to present his Hamnet co-star Emily Watson with the Richard Harris Award, given out to actors in celebration of their contribution to British film. Mescal, who took home the supporting performance BIFA in 2023 for All of Us Strangers, caught up with The Hollywood Reporter on the carpet ahead of the ceremony, where he revealed his favorite cinematic experience of 2025. “One Battle After Another,” he said. “[A] great cinema-going experience. Paul Thomas Anderson is a genius. The acting in it is phenomenal. It's my favorite Leo [DiCaprio] performance, I think.” When asked if he'd answer an incoming call from PTA, the Gladiator 2 and Aftersun star replied, laughing: “Is the sky blue? Of course, yeah. I would love to [work with him]…. I'm like, ‘Call me, please!'” Watson was tearful as she accepted the Richard Harris Award from her two-time co-star, who lauded her talent and generosity. The Oscar-nominated actress told her fellow creatives: “What you have to do is you have to reach out to those coming behind you, and you have to build relationships with younger colleagues, less certain of their path than you are. And that is actually the most rewarding part of the job, and it will ensure that we can help keep holding the algorithm to the fire.” Take a look at the roundup of winners at the British Independent Film Awards 2025 here. Amy Schumer Stuns in Tiny Valentino Dress After Revealing 30-Lb Weight Loss: PHOTOS
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-12-01 07:25:57

Amy Schumer is stepping out again, debuting a more sculpted and slimmer look. The comedian, 44, returned to Instagram with a new photo that showcased her trimmer silhouette and renewed commitment to feeling healthy. Weeks after wiping her feed and debuting a striking look at her toned figure, she continues to share the progress she has been working toward. In the new photo, Schumer sits on a stairwell in a beige Valentino Garavani pleated mini dress. The sleeveless design features soft bows and delicate ruffle details, creating a look that feels both playful and polished. She paired the dress with black pointy kitten-heeled sandals and kept her makeup fresh and understated. The post also included a sweet moment with her son, whose quick cameo added warmth and humor to the snapshot. “Trying to go to the party but someone won't go to bed @gitabass takin pics and painting me with @tousledbyjae dress by @maisonvalentino thanks @luxury_checkins skin as always by @georgialouisesk,” she wrote. Schumer's post quickly drew praise from friends and fellow celebrities. Kathy Hilton wrote, “Gorgeous!!!!” Brittany Snow chimed in with “Oh heyyyy,” and Krystyna Hutchinson added, “Hot d—m.” Actor Cheyenne Jackson also took notice, telling her, “You're glowing.” The outpouring of love comes after Schumer made headlines for wiping her older Instagram posts and sharing a photo in a red strapless mini dress. “Deleted my old pics for no reason!” she wrote at the time. After speculation tied her deleted posts to her weight loss, Schumer made it clear the assumption was false. “Hey media outlets, I didn't delete my old photos because they were pre-me losing weight,” she wrote in a later caption. “That's a narrative you created. I'm proud of how I've looked always. I have been working to be pain-free, and I finally am.” She shared that her recent changes are rooted in improving her health, not chasing a number on the scale. “My endometriosis is better. My back is healing. I no longer have Cushing syndrome, so my face went back to normal. I am grateful to be strong and healthy, especially for my son. But your Instagram is not your identity, it's a curation of what you want the world to see, and I feel great, strong and beautiful, and it's been fun sharing that,” she wrote.* Schumer stressed that her recent changes were never about following a scripted weight loss plan. “I didn't purposely go on a ‘weight loss journey,' that's a fine thing to go on. But my focus has been on health,” she said. “I'm sure my weight will always fluctuate. I'm a perimenopausal woman on HRT meds.” She closed her message with encouragement for anyone facing their own challenges. “Wishing you strength and self-love on whatever path you're on, as long as it's kind and respectful to all people. No matter their weight, race, or religion. Peace!” Her honesty resonated widely, drawing praise from fans and celebrities who applauded her focus on wellbeing, kindness, and body positivity. She didn't stun. Comment Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment. Δ Previous Next Like EntertainmentNow? Charlie Puth, Brandi Carlile, Coco Jones to Perform During 2026 Super Bowl Pregame
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-12-01 03:33:01

By Tomás Mier Coco Jones, Charlie Puth, and Brandi Carlile will join Bad Bunny as performers at the 2026 Super Bowl. On Sunday, the NFL announced that Puth will perform the national anthem, Jones will deliver “Lift Every Voice and Sing,” and Carlile will take on “America the Beautiful” before the League's top two teams face off at Super Bowl LX on Feb. 8. “Charlie, Brandi, and Coco are generational talents, and we are honored to have them – alongside our extraordinary deaf performers – on Super Bowl LX's world stage,” said Desiree Perez, CEO of Roc Nation, in a press release. “This moment embodies the very best of culture, live performance, and our country, perfectly kicking off game day.” The NFL also revealed that both the pregame and halftime shows will include American Sign Language interpreters, with Fred Beam performing “The Star-Spangled-Banner” and “Lift Every Voice and Sing,” and Julian Ortiz taking on “America the Beautiful.” The Big Game will also be the first time that a halftime show features a multilingual signing, with Celimar Rivera Cosme delivering Puerto Rican Sign Language at the event. “I can't believe I'm saying this… I will be performing the National Anthem at Super Bowl LX,” Puth captioned a silly post celebrating the news. In the clip, he breaks down the difficulty of singing “The Star-Spangled Banner” to a group of football players using game-day terminology — a nod to his social videos where he overexplains music. The video ends with him accidentally rallying the players into a chant of “Whose house? Our house!” Popular on Rolling Stone Puth, Carlile, and Jones will follow in the footsteps of Jon Batiste, Lauren Daigle, and Ledisi, who performed during the 2025 Super Bowl pregame festivities, which the Philadelphia Eagles won against the Kansas City Chiefs. Trending Stories Buddy Guy: ‘I'm the Last Old Man Playing the Blues' Millie Bobby Brown Says She and David Harbour Have a ‘Great Relationship' Amid Bullying Rumors Evanescence to Embark on 2026 World Tour: ‘It Feels Like Everything at the Right Time' ‘The Precedent Is Flint': How Oregon's Data Center Boom Is Supercharging a Water Crisis “Super Bowl Sunday is the world's biggest entertainment stage, and we're proud to spotlight artists who embody the very best of music and culture,” said Jon Barker, an NFL exec, in a press release. “Beyond the game itself, the Super Bowl is a global celebration. These artists bring a distinct voice to the moment, helping set the tone for a day that will captivate fans around the world.” The 2026 Super Bowl is scheduled for Feb. 8 on NBC, Telemundo, and Peacock. We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Rolling Stone is a part of Penske Media Corporation. © 2025 Rolling Stone, LLC. All rights reserved.

Super Bowl LX: Charlie Puth, Brandi Carlile and Coco Jones to Perform on Pregame Show
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2025-12-01 03:13:03

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Puth will perform the national anthem, Carlile will take on “America the Beautiful” and Jones will sing “Lift Every Voice and Sing.” By The Associated Press The Super Bowl pregame show will open with a trio of standout performers in Northern California: Charlie Puth will hit the stage to sing the national anthem, Brandi Carlile will take on “America the Beautiful” and Coco Jones will sing “Lift Every Voice and Sing.” The performances will take place Feb. 8 at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California, before the NFL's championship matchup and halftime show featuring Puerto Rican superstar Bad Bunny, the league said Sunday. “These artists bring a distinct voice to the moment, helping set the tone for a day that will captivate fans around the world,” said Jon Barker, senior vp global event production for the NFL. Related Video Related Stories TV NFL on Thanksgiving Day 2025: Here's Where to Watch All of the Games Live Online for Free TV 'Monday Night Football' Livestream: When and Where to Watch Carolina Panthers vs. San Francisco 49ers Online for Free The pregame performances will air on NBC, Telemundo and Peacock. The national anthem and “Lift Every Voice and Sing” will be performed by deaf performing artist Fred Beam in American Sign Language. Julian Ortiz will sign “America the Beautiful.” In a historic first, the halftime show will include a multilingual signing program featuring Puerto Rican Sign Language, led by interpreter Celimar Rivera Cosme. All signed performances for the pregame and halftime shows will be presented in collaboration with Alexis Kashar of LOVE SIGN and Howard Rosenblum of Deaf Equality. Puth is a four-time Grammy-nominated singer known for his songs “Attention,” “We Don't Talk Anymore” and his 2015 breakout hit “See You Again,” with Wiz Khalifa, from the Furious 7 movie soundtrack. His appearance will come ahead of his fourth studio album, Whatever's Clever!, due on March 6. Carlile has won 11 Grammys and won praise for her eighth studio album, Returning to Myself, which was released in October. She's nominated for two Grammys with Elton John for their album Who Believes in Angels?, released in April, and their song “Never Too Late,” from his documentary film Elton John: Never Too Late. Jones is an R&B star who won a Grammy in the best R&B performance category for her song “ICU” in 2024 and released her debut album, Why Not More?, which is nominated for best R&B album at next year's ceremony. She also stars as Hilary Banks on Peacock's television series Bel-Air, entering its last season. “Charlie, Brandi and Coco are generational talents, and we are honored to have them — alongside our extraordinary deaf performers — on Super Bowl LX's world stage,” said Desiree Perez, CEO of Roc Nation, which is producing the show with DPS and Jesse Collins. “This moment embodies the very best of culture, live performance and our country.” Sign up for THR news straight to your inbox every day Send us a tip using our anonymous form.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Aerosmith Has Now Achieved a New Top 10 Billboard 200 Album Six Decades in a Row
Source: Billboard    Published: 2025-12-01 01:45:40

Aerosmith joins an elite club with new top 10s in each decade from the 1970s-2020s, thanks to the act's new YUNGBLUD collab One More Time. By Keith Caulfield As Aerosmith and YUNGBLUD's collaborative album One More Time debuts at No. 9 on the Billboard 200 (dated Dec. 6), Aerosmith becomes the second group — and fifth act overall — with a newly-charting top 10 in each of the last six decades (1970s through 2020s). One More Time also marks the first top 10 for YUNGBLUD (after four earlier charting titles) and the 10th top 10 for Aerosmith. The latter was last in the top 10 with its last full-length studio album, 2012's Music From Another Dimension!, which debuted and peaked at No. 5. The Billboard 200 chart ranks the most popular albums of the week in the U.S. based on multi-metric consumption as measured in equivalent album units, compiled by Luminate. Units comprise album sales, track equivalent albums (TEA) and streaming equivalent albums (SEA). Each unit equals one album sale, or 10 individual tracks sold from an album, or 3,750 ad-supported or 1,250 paid/subscription on-demand official audio and video streams generated by songs from an album. The new Dec. 6, 2025-dated chart will be posted in full on Billboard‘s website on Dec. 2. For all chart news, follow @billboard and @billboardcharts on both X, formerly known as Twitter, and Instagram. Aerosmith notched its first top 10 on the Billboard 200 in 1976 (and only top 10 of the ‘70s) with Rocks (peaking at No. 3). The band then scored one top 10 in the ‘80s (1989's No. 5-peaking Pump), three in the ‘90s (Get a Grip, No. 1; Big Ones, No. 6 and Nine Lives, No. 1), three in the 2000s (Just Push Play, No. 2; O, Yeah! Ultimate Aerosmith Hits, No. 2 and Honkin' On Bobo, No. 5), one in the ‘10s (Music From Another Dimension!, No. 5) and now one in the '20s with One More Time. Aerosmith is the second group, following The Rolling Stones, with at least one newly-charting top 10 in every decade from the 1970s through the 2020s. Among all acts, there are just five with a new top 10 in each decade in that span: Aerosmith, Paul McCartney, The Rolling Stones, Bruce Springsteen and James Taylor. The five-track One More Time was preceded by its first single, “My Only Angel,” which debuted at No. 1 on Hot Hard Rock Songs in October and climbs 7-6 (a new peak) on the most recently published Mainstream Rock Airplay chart (dated Dec. 6). On the latter ranking, “My Only Angel” marked the 25th top 10 for Aerosmith and the first for YUNGBLUD. “My Only Angel” is the first top 10 for Aerosmith on the Mainstream Rock Airplay chart since 2004's “Baby, Please Don't Go” reached No. 7, and the band's highest-charting hit since “Jaded” spent five weeks at No. 1 in 2001. Get weekly rundowns straight to your inbox A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Billboard is a part of Penske Media Corporation. © 2025 Billboard Media, LLC. All Rights Reserved.

Patrice ‘Sway' McKinney, Porsha Williams' Girlfriend: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-12-01 00:57:00

Patrice “Sway” McKinney is the woman who has officially captured Porsha Williams' heart and become the newest name everyone in “The Real Housewives of Atlanta” universe is talking about. After months of speculation, Williams went public with her new girlfriend on Instagram — and fans have a lot of questions about Sway's career, success, and how the couple met. Here's what you need to know. Williams confirmed her new relationship on November 28, sharing a photo with McKinney and a sweet birthday shoutout. “Happiest Birthday @sway_thepro,” Williams wrote. “Hope this year continues to bring you everything you want and more! Can't wait to act up Saturday!” The post arrived just two months after Williams shared that she had been dating both a man and a woman. Judging from her latest update, things appear official with McKinney. Fans instantly reacted to the news. Some questioned how fast Williams dives into relationships, while others loved the match. As one fan commented, “Happy looks amazing on you. There's a special kind of freedom that comes from living life on your own terms.” McKinney also replied under the post, writing, “Damn babe. Sweet af. Thank you again!” McKinney is more than a reality TV romance — she's a licensed master barber and entrepreneur who built a successful salon empire in Atlanta. According to Recession Money on Instagram, McKinney has earned about $1.7 million from her business ventures. She first worked behind the chair before launching her own salon and barbershop in 2014. “I had good clientele, but I was tired of standing on my feet all day,” McKinney said in an interview with EPYC. “My dream was to be able to take care of my family, buy my dream car and home and travel.” By 2017, McKinney began teaching others how to build their own salon-suites. Her company has helped hundreds of stylists launch their own locations. McKinney founded Encore Salon Suites, a franchise-style salon suite model that expanded into multiple locations in the Atlanta area. She runs an online training platform that teaches salon owners business systems and growth strategies. Her focus, she says, is helping others avoid costly business mistakes: “I want to save people the hassle of making mistakes that could cost thousands.” Williams publicly confirmed their relationship at BravoCon 2025. She told the audience the cast met her “female friend” at Drew Sidora's premiere of her film Fair Love. A video already circulating online showed Williams introducing McKinney to her co-stars before she confirmed the news. While McKinney's exact net worth is unknown — rumored to be $1.7 million — her business ventures, franchises, coaching platform, and influencer work suggest she was already financially thriving before her relationship with Williams. OTHER

Scientists sending spacecraft to search for aliens on Saturn's moon
Source: Tioga Publishing    Published: 2025-12-01 18:58:19

Artist's impression of Saturn's icy moon Enceladus, which has a frozen surface covering a deep ocean. Jets of water burst from cracks close to the moon's south pole. (ESA via SWNS) By Dean Murray Scientists are to send a spacecraft to hunt for aliens potentially hiding in our solar system. The European Space Agency (ESA) has announced a mission to Saturn's moon Enceladus, as it has all the ingredients needed for lifeforms. The agency set out the mission in its Voyage2050 long-term planning period announcement. Enceladus is Saturn's sixth-largest moon, a 500 km-wide icy world famed for its south polar geysers spewing water plumes from a subsurface ocean. Artist's impression depicts thermal plumes venting from the southern polar region of Saturn's moon Enceladus. The moon's icy shell is thought to overlay a global ocean. (ESA via SWNS) ESA said: "No space agency has ever landed on Enceladus. And yet this moon has enormous potential for new science, particularly in the realm of habitability. "It checks all the boxes when it comes to conditions for a ‘habitable environment' to potentially support life as we know it." The agency added that the moon has liquid water, a source of energy, and a specific set of chemical elements. This artist's impression shows a concept for a future ocean world explorer. (ESA via SWNS) Agency officials described Enceladus as a "top target for us" and plan to send a spacecraft to land on the moon. They added: "Pinning down what can be done with the resources that we will have in the 2040s, we aim high. Our plan is to fly through Enceladus' jets and even land on the moon's south polar terrain to collect samples. This artist's impression shows a cross section of Saturn's icy moon Enceladus, which includes a rocky core, an ocean and an icy shell. Jets of water are seen bursting from cracks. (ESA via SWNS) "The impact of such a mission could be enormous for Europe and beyond. The mission would boost European competences in many scientific and technological fields, including in-orbit assembly, operating in extreme environments, landing technologies, and novel scientific instrumentation. "Decisions at our upcoming Council at Ministerial level will be crucial for securing Europe's leadership in planetary science for decades to come. "Studies for this ambitious mission have already begun." Originally published on talker.news, part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange. Your browser is out of date and potentially vulnerable to security risks.We recommend switching to one of the following browsers:
